titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I suffer still from the cold which I caught at Prince Radziwill’s— Took a walk in the park. Evening again at home, and read a Canto, in the faery queene.— Princess of Orange has a daughter.

2. No Court this day— Long walk in the park;— Read a sermon of Tillotson in the morning— And in the Evening, in Spenser— The 6th: of the second book— One of the finest I have yet read.— It contains the house of wealth—or Mammon.

3. In the evening at a ball at Mr: Dorville’s— All the royal family there— Play’d whist with Madame de Sartoris, Madame de Marwitz and the Minister Buchholz. Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Dr: Brown’s; with Mrs: Payne; late Miss Elliot of Dresden, who is here upon her way to England.

4. Large party and supper this Evening at Count Schulenburg’s— Garlike introduced me to General Stamford: the Prince of Orange’s Minister here.— Play’d whist with Madame de Reck; the Minister Heinitz, and Count Wartensleben; whom I brought home with me afterwards.

5. A ball at which all the royal family were present, at the Minister Schroetter’s— A very large company even for Berlin— Play’d whist with Mlle: de Hagen, Mlle: d’Eichstett, and Count Lindenau— Mrs: A. was in the morning and spent the Evening with Mrs: O’Farrill— Have still a bad cold.

6. Concert at the Opera house, for which we took tickets, but it was so cold that we could not go. Reaumur’s thermometer was this evening at 9 degrees below 0, At this time a year a more extraordinary degree of cold than 20. in January— Evening at home— Read a Canto of the fairy queen; but was so hoarse, I could read no more— 8 Stanza’s of Oberon— But Mr: Catel criticises my present performances much more than he did heretofore.

7. Spent part of the Evening at Doctor Brown’s— The weather continues very cold— Am too much occupied by my translation of Oberon— Finished the sixth book, and began upon the 7th:— Have now got half through the poem— Found Mr: Arbuthnot at Dr: Brown’s.
8. Evening party at Mr: Rochow’s— Play’d reversi with the princess of Sweden, Countess Haugwitz and Count Byland.— Home between 9 and 10.

9. Read a sermon of Tillotson— Coll: Swan called upon me this forenoon— Received an insolent letter from C. A. Kierrulf.— Mr: Ellison called on me in the evening to shew me the answer he proposes to publish to Kierrulf’s libel. Afterwards sent me a postscript, which I do not altogether approve.

10. Sent for Mr: Ellison, who called on me at length in the afternoon, and agreed to make an alteration in his postscript, to make it conformable to rigorous truth.— He assured me he should leave town this Evening. The queen’s birth-day— A ball at Court.— Mrs: A. proposed to go, but at length concluded to stay at home. I came home soon after 9.— Play’d whist with Count Goltz; a Swedish Count, and Mr: Helbig. The cold weather has continued every night from the beginning of this month, and this evening was at 10. below 0.

12. Mr: Welsh went to Potsdam with Coll: Swan.— Dined at Mr: Schickler’s— A company of about 25. persons— Mr: and Madame Cabarrus—Genl: Beurnonville & his legation—Mr: Duroveray &c. Mrs: A. being unwell could not go. Evening at home and read a Canto of the faery queen.

11. Had a lesson of German this morning. And found the Stanza’s of Oberon so troublesome, that I did nothing else the whole day— Read only a tale in the Volksmährchen der Deutschen—called Dämon Amor. The first in the volume is by far the best.

13. The tone and style of poetry in the last half of the Oberon, differs much from that of the first. It is much more difficult— The labour of it has become nearly insufferable— Read a book in the faery queen. It contains a Chronicle of Briton kings, from Brute till Uther’s reign; and rolls of Elfin Emperours, till time of Gloriana. One of the most curious Canto’s, though tedious to read.— Mr: Welsh came home from Potsdam.

14. Find the Oberon again a little more practicable— Wrote in the forenoon. Evening at the Minister Heinitz’s weekly party— Play’d whist with him, General Beurnonville and Mr Knoblauch— Miss Bisschofwerder paid a visit to Mrs: A. in the morning, and Countess Haugwitz after dinner— The weather has at last grown moderate.
15. The weather fine— Lesson for examination of my translation, which is at present all I do.— Walk’d in the park forenoon and afternoon— Read a Canto of the faery queen in the evening.
16. Walk’d again, morning and afternoon— Read a sermon of Tillotson— Coll: Swan and Miss Brown pass’d most of the evening with us— Read to Miss Brown about a book of my translation.

17. Mr: Arbuthnot called upon me in the forenoon between 11 and 12. Went with him and attended Mr: Ancillon’s historical lecture— His subject was the civil wars of France at the time of the league. Walk’d afterwards in the park— Was so hoarse with a cold that I could not this evening read aloud.

18. Walk’d both in the forenoon and towards evening.— Read a Canto in the faery Queene— The last of the second book, or the legend of Sir Guyon, or of temperance— It contains the description of the bower of bliss
19. The day as yesterday— The Oberon has now engross’d almost all my time— Read the first Canto of the third book of the faery queene— The legend of Britomartis or of chastity.

20. A great and splendid ball this evening at Count Hatzfelt’s— The first opening of his house since his marriage— Played whist with Countess Haugwitz, Count Redern, and Mr: Knoblauch— Came home before supper.
21. Walk’d morning and afternoon. Miss Brown spent the Evening with us— Read the remainder of the fourth and the fifth book of the Oberon.

22. Mr: Arbuthnot spent part of the evening with us.— My German lessons have become exclusively devoted to an examination of my translation, and the work my sole occupation— I might likewise almost say my sole amusement.

23. Read a sermon of Tillotson in the forenoon— Did over anew a stanza, which teaz’d me yesterday two or three hours and which was after all very ill done.— Continued to work upon the same book all the afternoon and evening.
24. The weather again cold— Thermometer at 6. below 0. Finish’d the seventh book of the Oberon, and read it this evening to Mrs: Adams.

25— Mr: Catel this morning— Began the eighth book of Oberon— I find that with some difficulty I can do six Stanza’s a day, and henceforth shall seldom attempt to do more.— Spent the Evening and supp’d at Mr: Schickler’s— Music— Play’d whist with Baron Krüdener, Mr: von Axen (Mrs: Schickler’s father) and Mr: Cabarrus.

26. Mrs: Adams past the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s— I was there about an hour— Look’d over the last splendid edition of Milton’s poems. with prints from Westall’s paintings— The prints, almost without exception are very bad.— There are 3 volumes and the price is 21. Guineas.

27. The weather has become fine. Ball and supper at the Marquis de Lucchesini’s. The royal family all there. The Queen’s youngest child is very ill, so that she came late.— Play’d whist with Mlle. de Hagen—Mlle. Eichstett, and General Beurnonville.
28. Miss Hagen and Miss Dunderfelt call’d this morning to see Mrs: Adams.— Read this Evening a Canto of the faery queene, which I begin to find tedious.— But I read nothing else.
29. Walking towards evening under the trees I met the Chevalier d’Aguilar and walk’d with him rather late.— Wrote a short letter to Mr: Murray at Paris— In the Evening a book of Pope’s Iliad.

30. The king’s youngest daughter died this evening.— At Prince Ferdinand’s— Play’d whist with the Princess Radziwill, Madame de Reede, and Baron de Hagen— Coll: Swan called here in the morning— He goes for Hamburg in a couple of days— Visit this evening from M. d’Araujo.

31. Weather for some days past has been extremely beautiful and warm— Long walk this morning and in the afternoon with Mrs: A— Countess Brühl and her daughter Mary spent the evening with Mrs: A.— Letter from Mr: Bourne.
Day— as the last months.
